li.p: The phrase structure of ellipsis in NP
Ellipsis, proper government, and the Empty Category Principle

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The study of ellipsis in noun phrases originates as part of a broader investigation of ellipsis as null anaphora, where missing material is interpreted under identity with an antecedent in much the same way as a lexical pronoun. Some examples are given in (1–3) below, where in each, the ellipsis site is interpreted under identity with an antecedent in the previous discourse:
(1) The committee endorses every bill the president proposes but the advisors approve only a few [e].
(2) I really liked this book and I know you’ll like these [e].
(3) The students went to the bookstore and each [e] bought a book by Chomsky.

Early analyses of ellipsis explore the hypothesis that null and lexical anaphors are constrained by the same universal principles. Indeed, in early work in generative syntax, ellipsis in English noun phrases (typically referred to as N′ anaphora or N′ ellipsis) is analyzed as resulting from a deletion transformation, one's deletion, in which ellipsis results from deletion of a lexical proform. The status of the one's deletion transformation figures prominently in early debates between proponents of the ‘deletion’ approach to null anaphora and advocates of the ‘interpretation’ approach, where empty categories are base-generated and subject to rules of interpretation. Ellipis in noun phrases is subsequently analyzed within the Principles and Parameters framework as involving proper government of pro, an empty pronominal category, licensed by what is ultimately argued to be a functional category DET, the head of DP. This approach leads to in-depth, cross-linguistic analyses of the properties of the determiner and quantifier systems to determine the feature specifications of different functional heads, and the role those features play in licensing and identification. This research also explores connections between ellipsis in DP and substantive adjective and partitive constructions, in particular partitives which involve clitic en (French) and ne (Italian).

subsection.heading: 2 Ellipsis as null anaphora
subsection.p: Ross (1986; original dissertation 1967) is the first to investigate the parallels between ellipsis and lexical pronouns. His crucial insight is that ellipsis phenomena in general (VP ellipsis, sluicing, and ellipsis in NP) appear to violate the same cluster of constraints also violated by pronouns, that is, constraints respected by movement rules. Moreover, other phenomena involving ‘missing’ constituents, such as gapping and comparative deletion, do not exhibit this behavior, and thus appear to be distinct from ellipsis. Specifically, Ross observes that both pronouns and ellipsis obey the Backwards Anaphora Constraint (BAC) (see also Langacker 1966), but violate both the Complex NP Constraint (CNPC) and the Coordinate Structure Constraint (CSC). (See also Hankamer 1971.)

That ellipsis sites, like pronouns, obey the BAC is illustrated in (4–7), which show that both pronouns and ellipsis sites can precede their antecedents, but only when contained in subordinate but not coordinate clauses:

(4)
a. John enjoys waking up early, and he likes to see the sunrise.
b. *He enjoys waking up early and John likes to see the sunrise.

(5)
a. John enjoys waking up early because he likes to see the sunrise.
b. Because he likes to see the sunrise, John enjoys waking up early.

(6)
a. Each student woke up early and all [e] saw the sunrise.
b. *All [e] saw the sunrise, and each student woke up early.

(7)
a. Each student woke up early because all [e] wanted to see the sunrise.
b. Because all [e] wanted to see the sunrise, each student woke up early.
(8) illustrates that both pronouns and ellipsis can be contained in NPs that do not also contain their antecedents. In Ross's terms, pronouns and ellipsis thus violate the CNPC:

(8)
a. We heard that Mary likes [NP the man who talked to her at the party].
b. Most people liked Mary's presentation, but I also talked to [NP a number of people who didn't like Sue's [e]].
That pronouns and ellipsis violate the CSC is illustrated in (9), where the pronoun and ellipsis site are contained in coordinate clauses that do not also contain their antecedents:

(9)
a. [John saw Mary] and [she said hello to him].
b. [John read Mary's book] and [she read his [e]].

In current terms, what we might view as null anaphors in ellipsis contexts seem to obey Principle B of the Binding Theory in (10), just like lexical pronouns. That is, like pronouns, ellipsis sites are free in their binding domain, which we can informally define here as the clause containing them. (This does not apply to Antecedent-Contained Ellipsis, which will not be discussed here.)

(10)
Binding Theory:
A An anaphor must be bound in its binding domain.
B A pronoun must be free in its binding domain.
C An R-expression must be free.
Ross exploits this connection between ellipsis and pronominalization, proposing that the source of ellipsis in noun phrases is in fact the pronoun one, which is deleted by a transformational rule.

subsection.heading: 2.1 One's deletion
subsection.p: Ross proposes that one's deletion involves replacement of part of NP at deep structure by the pronoun one, as in (11b), and subsequent deletion of this pronoun by transformational rule, to derive the surface structure in (11c):

(11)
a. Mary bought two books on astronomy, and she read [both books on astronomy] last night. (deep structure)
b. Mary bought two books on astronomy, and she read [both ones] last night. (one pronominalization)
c. Mary bought two books on astronomy, and she read [both] last night. (one's deletion)

Deriving ellipsis in noun phrases by one's deletion raises a number of questions that suggest that it can be the source of ellipsis only at a certain cost to the grammar. Investigation of the strengths and weaknesses of one's deletion lays important groundwork for discussions of deletion vs. interpretation, and whether it is in fact explanatory to derive elliptical constructions from deletion of lexical pronominal counterparts. One's deletion also raises questions about the internal structure of the noun phrase, and highlights the different distribution of prenominal elements that can successfully introduce the ellipted category in NP in English.

One immediate issue that arises in a one's-deletion approach to ellipsis is that it requires certain cases of ellipsis in noun phrases to derive from ungrammatical sources. Jackendoff (1971) points out, for example, that the sentence in (12a) must derive from the ungrammatical sentence in (12b) (see also Perlmutter 1970a; Sommerstein 1972). A one's-deletion analysis is therefore particularly problematic for deriving ellipsis in mass noun phrases:

(12)
a. Max's wine was good but Bill's [e] was even better.
b. *Max's wine was good but Bill's one was even better.

Jackendoff (1977) circumvents the problem of one's deletion by proposing that ellipsis in noun phrases derives not from deletion, but rather from noun phrases with base-generated, empty pronominal (PRO) heads. Determiners preceding PRO undergo a ‘substantivization’ rule, given in (13):

(13)
ART - PRO fi 1 + substantive - 2
OBLIGATORY
This rule derives the ellipsis constructions in (14):
(14) John wanted to read the dossiers of famous linguists, and/but he succeeded in reading [Morris's/some/many/one/mine/three/none/these/every one PRO] NP
Substantivization has the additional effect of converting certain determiners into the appropriate phonological forms before PRO, as illustrated in (15):

(15)
a. every + PRO = every one + PRO
b. no + PRO = none + PRO
c. my + PRO = mine + PRO

Jackendoff (see also Selkirk 1977) explicitly connects the syntax of ellipsis in noun phrases to that of partitive noun phrases, arguing that both dominate PRO heads, and that as a result, both undergo substantivization of a determiner or quantifier. The partitive noun phrase each of the trees, for example, has the internal structure in (16), and the ellipsis construction each [e] has the structure in (17):
(16) [N″ each [N″ [N′ PRO of [N″ the trees]]]]

(17)
a. [N″ each [N″ tree]]
b. [N″ each [N″ PRO]]

In both (16) and (17b), PRO triggers substantivization of the quantifier each. Jackendoff predicts that both elliptical and partitive noun phrases will exhibit the same changes in phonological shape of the quantifier or determiner that precedes PRO. He therefore predicts that in ellipsis constructions, the quantifiers every and no are realized as every one and none before PRO, just as they are in partitives:

(18)
a. every one of the men/*every PRO of the men
b. every one PRO/*every PRO

(19)
a. none PRO/*no of the men
b. none PRO/*no PRO

Perlmutter (1970a) notes further problems with one's deletion, observing that although prenominal adjectives can introduce the N′ pronominalized by one, one's deletion in these contexts is nevertheless ungrammatical. (See Baker 1978 and Hornstein and Lightfoot 1981 for arguments that one pronominalization replaces N′.)

(20)
a. Svetlana has two red masks and Guido has a green *(one).
b. Svetlana has two red masks and Guido has one too.
c. *Svetlana has two red masks and Guido has a one too.

Perlmutter explains these facts by proposing that there exist in English both a pronoun one and a numeral one, and further, that the English indefinite article is the unstressed counterpart of the numeral one. (See also Jackendoff 1977 for discussion of two possible derivations of one.) This proposal explains a set of recalcitrant ellipsis facts, in addition to those illustrated in (20).
Perlmutter argues that the phrase a green one in (20a) actually derives from the grammatical source in (21), where the numeral one is unstressed, and thus can reduce to a:
(21) one green one ⇒ a green one
To block the ungrammatical (20c), Perlmutter proposes that unstressed pronominal one is obligatorily deleted after a numeral. The source of (20c) is thus (22):
(22) Svetlana has two red masks and Guido has one one too.
Unstressed pronominal one in (22) will obligatorily delete, deriving the grammatical (23):
(23) Svetlana has two red masks and Guido has one too.
Further evidence for this claim is given in (24–25), where we see that pronominal one deletes only after numerals, but not after adjectives:
(24) Svetlana sells red masks and Guido sells green ones

(25)
a. *Svetlana sold three masks and Guido sold four ones.
b. Svetlana sold three masks and Guido sold four.
An account in which a is the unstressed counterpart of the stressed full numeral one also explains the contrast illustrated in (26):

(26)
a. *a village in Greece and a (an) in Yugoslavia.
b. a village in Greece and one in Yugoslavia.

According to Perlmutter, (26a) is ruled out because a is a proclitic with no host to which to attach. Under such conditions only the stressed full form of the article, namely the numeral one, can appear.

Though Perlmutter's analysis makes certain correct predictions about ellipsis in indefinite noun phrases (and a variety of other data involving the distribution of the indefinite article a), the analysis is unavoidably ad hoc, as it must stipulate that one obligatorily deletes after numerals, but not after adjectives. We are thus left without an explanation for the ungrammaticality of the (b) sentences in (27–28). In these sentences, unstressed a can cliticize to new, but ellipsis is nevertheless ungrammatical:

(27)
a. Svetlana sells old masks and Guido sells new ones.
b. *Svetlana sells old masks and Guido sells new.

(28)
a. Svetlana wants to sell an old mask and Guido wants to sell a new one.
b. *Svetlana wants to sell an old mask and Guido wants to sell a new.
In addition, as Perlmutter himself points out (fn. 6), it appears that certain determiners other than numerals trigger obligatory deletion of one:

(29)
a. *my flag and hers one
b. my flag and hers
Again, it remains to explain why one's deletion is obligatory in (29b), but blocked after adjectives.

Other early approaches to one's deletion address the status of personal pronouns, such as we, you, she, etc. Postal (1969) argues that personal pronouns are definite articles that derive from noun phrases in which they are followed by the pronoun one. One deletes by a late (and, Postal admits, ad hoc) rule deriving the forms in (30b) from the sources in (30a). The status of pronouns as determiners thus emerges early on in discussions of ellipsis in noun phrases:

(30)
a. we ones/you one/she one
b. we/you/she

Sommerstein (1972) takes the opposite approach, claiming that the definite article the is a pronoun, replacing a full NP. He gives a number of arguments against Postal's analysis of pronouns as determiners, based on evidence from Greek, a language which allows constructions analogous to English the in London and the loved by Rebecca. He argues that in English count-noun phrases, one must be inserted after the in order to derive the one in London and the one loved by Rebecca. Thus, his approach includes an obligatory rule of one insertion, which inserts one in count-noun phrases to replace a deleted N-head. One insertion is similar in spirit to do support, inserting a dummy element to realize features, in this case, number. As for ellipsis in noun phrases, he provides only an account of the ungrammatical (31):
(31) *The cheese in this package is fresher than the in that package.
He proposes that the must be altered to the stronger form that in order to derive the grammatical sentence in (32):
(32) *The cheese in this package is fresher than that in that package.
For related discussion of personal pronouns as determiners, and whether or not they are followed by empty categories, see Corblin (1990), Hewson (1991), and Luján (2000).

subsection.heading: 2.2 Deletion vs. interpretation
subsection.p: Researchers in the 1960s and 1970s generally concur with Ross that ellipsis is a type of null anaphora, but not all agree with his claim that both pronouns and ellipsis are derived by the same (in early frameworks, transformational) rules. There is extensive debate concerning whether ellipsis phenomena (in particular, VP ellipsis and sluicing) are derived by deletion of a copy of an antecedent (with or without the intermediate step of pronominalization as Ross proposes), or whether ellipses are base-generated empty structures, whose content is supplied by rules of interpretation (the ‘interpretive’ approach, an early illustration of which is Jackendoff's analysis of empty N as PRO). Of central concern in these debates is the definition of ‘identity’ between null anaphors and their antecedents, and more specifically, whether null anaphors have internal structure, and if so, which grammatical model best expresses how such structure is derived and interpreted. Work toward resolving these issues leads researchers to sharpen the distinction between ellipsis and other phenomena involving missing material, such as gapping, comparative deletion, stripping, and null complement anaphora, and to move toward a grammatical model which requires a distinct level of Logical Form.

In general, early arguments that ellipsis is derived by deletion under identity hinge on the evidence that an ellipsis site must, at some level of the derivation, have internal syntactic structure in order for the missing phrase to be properly interpreted. Such arguments are raised partially in response to Akmajian's (1968) ‘non-expansion hypothesis’, in which null anaphors are base-generated as empty, unexpanded non-terminals, associated with their antecedents through rules of interpretation. (Proponents of the strict transformational position on the derivation of anaphora include Postal 1972; Hankamer 1973a; Morgan 1973; Ross 1986; and most of the pre-Aspects literature (Chomsky 1965). Defenders of the interpretive approach include Dougherty 1969; Jackendoff 1969, 1971, 1977; Shopen 1972; Wasow 1972; Fiengo 1974; Williams 1977.)

How the notion of ‘syntactic identity’ is articulated, however, depends on the model of grammar defended. For instance, Wasow (1972) proposes an interpretive theory in which null anaphors are base-generated empty categories with internal structure to which interpretive rules apply. Lexical pronouns, on the other hand, have no internal structure, and are also subject to interpretive rules. Williams (1977) defines syntactic identity in terms of identity of Logical Form, rather than strict surface structure identity, arguing that an ellipsis and its antecedent are related by interpretive rules that apply at LF (in his model, Discourse Grammar). Deletion rules, on the other hand, are restricted to applying to surface structures (Sentence Grammar), to operations that obey Ross's Constraints, such as gapping and comparative deletion. In Williams's model ellipsis (including sluicing, ellipsis in NP, and VP ellipsis) is distinct from gapping and comparative deletion. In Sag's (1980) model, ellipsis, comparative deletion, and gapping are all derived by deletion, an operation that in the case of ellipsis applies to logical forms, in a model of grammar quite different from Williams's. Hankamer and Sag (1976) further elucidate this deletion approach, arguing that ellipsis patterns with stripping and gapping as an instance of “surface” rather than “deep” anaphora, based on, for example, the claim that surface but not deep anaphors require linguistic antecedents. (See Schachter 1977 and Chao 1988 for arguments that ellipsis can have pragmatic antecedents, and Lobeck 1995 for specific arguments that this holds of ellipsis in noun phrases. See also Williams 1977, who suggests (fn. 6) that anaphoric elements dominated by N and NP can be pragmatically controlled, and that all others require linguistic control. There is thus, in his view, no difference between deep and surface anaphora, and no implicit argument for deletion based on the presence or absence of pragmatic control.)

subsection.heading: 3 The phrase structure of ellipsis in NP
subsection.p: Much of the early research on ellipsis in NP assumes without argument that ellipsis operates on a projection of N, but other work on Germanic and Romance languages explores the phrase structure of ellipsis in more detail, providing important evidence for bar-level distinctions in NP, and sharpening structural distinctions among the different prenominal elements that introduce those projections. This early research on the phrase structure of ellipsis in noun phrases lays important groundwork for arguments that noun phrases are projections of the category Determiner, and for analyzing ellipsis in such phrases as ellipsis in DP.

Jackendoff (1971, 1977) examines certain crucial differences between gapping and ellipsis in NP and VP first noted by Ross (1986), and concludes that gapping and ellipsis in these categories are different operations, (for him, gapping, but not ellipsis, involves deletion), but that both operate on N′, the lowest projection of N. He bases this conclusion on evidence that prenominal adjectives must be included in both operations. An example of ellipsis is given in (33), based on evidence in Jackendoff (1971). (The example is constructed with the ellipsis in a subordinate clause, to distinguish ellipsis from gapping, which cannot occur in subordinate clauses, as pointed out early on by both Ross 1986 and Jackendoff 1971, among others.)

(33)
Tureck's performance of Bach on the piano doesn't please me as much as
a. *[NP Glenn Gould's [N′ fabulous [e]].
b. [NP Glenn Gould's [N′ e]]
Ellipsis must also include N and its complements, as illustrated in (34), with an example based on the discussion in Jackendoff (1977):
(34) *Although [NP Max's [N′ [e] about Sue]] was amazing, Bill's story about her was virtually incredible.

Ronat (1977) comes to the opposite conclusion for French, claiming that in contrast to English, in French N′ cannot be empty. Her arguments hinge on evidence that only elements that are dominated by N′ can introduce an ellipted (for her, deleted) noun. Ellipsis of N is impossible with other adjectives or relative clauses dominated by higher projections of N, as ellipsis in this case would leave N′ empty. The relevant contrasts are given below. (See also Milner 1973, 1974 and Kayne 1975 for arguments regarding the distribution of adjectival modifiers and quantifiers in French, and Barbaud 1976 for the distribution of adjectives in French noun phrases.)

(35)
a. [NP les [N′ deux [N e]]]
the two [e]
‘the two’
b. [NP la [[N′ e] verte]]
the
green
‘the green (one)’

(36)
*[NP le [N′ e]]
the [e]
‘the one’

(37)
*[NP le [N′ e] qui est susceptible de te plaire]
the
that is susceptible of you please
‘the (one) that pleases you’

(38)
*[NP le [N′ e] susceptible de te plaire]
susceptible of you please
‘the (one) that pleases you’

(39)
*[NP les [N′ e] magnifiques]
the
magnificent(s)
‘the magnificent (ones)’

In an alternative approach to substantive adjective constructions in French, Herschensohn (1978) argues that, contrary to the analysis proposed by Gouet (1976), certain substantive adjectives are deep anaphors, rather than derived by deletion of a noun, as Gouet proposes. Herschensohn bases her claim on evidence that such constructions can take pragmatic antecedents, a criterion for identification as a deep anaphor, according to Hankamer and Sag (1976). Other, superficially similar constructions require syntactic control, and are thus surface anaphors, involving deleted nouns.
For example, the contrast between (40) and (41) suggests that the substantive adjective petits requires a linguistic antecedent and is thus a surface anaphor, derived by deletion of a noun:

(40)
Il y avait de grands garçons et de petits aussi.
there were of big boys and of little too
‘There were big boys and little (ones) too.’

(41)
[Two individuals are looking out a window at (among other things) boys playing]
#Il y avait de petits aussi.
there were of little too
‘There were little (ones) too.’
Herschensohn contrasts the substantive adjectival constructions with those discussed by Gouet, which involve regional and brand names. These adjectives appear to be pragmatically controlled:

(42)
[Individual standing at a bar]
Un bourgogne blanc, s’il vous plaît.
a burgundy white if you please
‘A (glass of) white Burgundy (wine) please.’
In Herschensohn's view, certain substantive adjectives, namely those involving brand names, do not involve deletion of a noun, while others, which require syntactic control, do.

Ronat's work shifts the focus of ellipsis in noun phrases from deletion vs. interpretation to the elements that introduce the ellipted category, and explicitly connects ellipsis with constructions involving partitive en. Ronat adopts Kayne's (1975) claim that quantifiers and numerals are dominated by N′, and argues that in (43), the empty noun is therefore sister to a numeral in N′. Ronat analyzes such constructions as involving ellipsis, and claims that ellipsis is grammatical because only N, but not N′, is empty:

(43)
J’ en ai mangé [NP
[N′ un [e]].
I of-them have eaten one
‘I have eaten one of them.’
See 4.3 for further discussion of connections between ellipsis in noun phrases and partitive en constructions.

subsection.heading: 4 Ellipsis, proper government, and the Empty Category Principle
subsection.p: Within the Principles and Parameters framework of the early 1980s, empty categories are argued to be base-generated, with their syntactic distribution constrained by various interacting principles of government (in particular ‘proper’ government) and binding. Within this framework, the focus on ellipsis shifts from deletion vs. interpretation to whether empty categories in ellipsis constructions can be argued to fit into a larger typology of empty [+/−pronominal, +/−anaphor] elements, based on the syntactic conditions under which they are licit.

Zagona (1982, 1988a, 1988b) is first to analyze empty VP in ellipsis constructions as typologically pro, an empty pronominal category, constrained by principles of proper government and the Empty Category Principle or ECP of Chomsky (1981). Her analysis captures the earlier generalization that ellipses, like pronouns, seem exempt from Ross's Constraints, and in terms of the Principles and Parameters framework, subject to Principle B of the Binding Theory. (Recall that for Jackendoff 1972, 1977, ellipsis in noun phrases involves an empty PRO, which one might argue is another early precursor of pro. Wasow 1972 also suggests that ellipted constituents are base-generated empty proforms.) Zagona argues that empty pro VP in English and Spanish must be properly governed by a head specified for ‘rich’ agreement, on a par with empty subjects in Romance (Rizzi 1982a). Zagona argues that empty VP satisfies the ECP when properly governed by INFL, and that INFL is only a proper governor when specified for rich agreement features (in this case, Tense features). (See also Chao 1988, who argues that pro in VP ellipsis and sluicing constructions is constrained by the ECP.)

The following sections outline the progression of ECP analyses of ellipsis in noun phrases, from ‘specifier’ government to proper government by the functional categories DET, Q, and NUM. This research sharpens the distinction between ellipsis and substantive adjective constructions, and clarifies connections between empty N in ellipsis constructions and partitives in which ellipted N alternates with the trace of partitive en/ne.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Specifier government in NP
subsection.p: In a first attempt at analyzing ellipsis in NP in the Principles and Parameters framework, Lobeck (1987) extends Zagona's approach to VP ellipsis to both sluicing and ellipsis in noun phrases in English (with a short discussion of French), in an attempt to provide a unified, ECP approach to the distribution of empty categories in ellipsis constructions across categories. She argues that pro in ellipsis constructions must be properly governed by a specifier (and thus subject to ‘specifier government’), and that SPEC–HEAD agreement features of tense, possession, number, etc. suffice to designate certain specifiers as proper governors. In her framework ellipted projections of N must be properly governed by SPEC(N) specified as [+number] or [+poss], as illustrated in (44). Quantifiers are specified as [+number] in her approach even when singular, accounting for the grammaticality of (44e):

(44)
a. The committee endorses every bill the president proposes but the advisors approve only [NP a [few [e]].
b. I really liked those books and I know you’ll like [NP these [e]].
c. Sally discussed the committee's decision to vote yes before she mentioned [NP the president's [e]].
d. Even though she already has [NP two [e]], Mary bought three more dogs yesterday.
e. The students went to the bookstore and [NP each [e]] bought a book by Chomsky.

Lobeck adopts Emonds's (1985) arguments that certain grammatical formatives are inserted late in the derivation, and thus unavailable as surface structure proper governors. Possessive NPs, demonstratives, and certain quantifiers are, for example, deep structure SPEC(N), but definite and indefinite articles and the quantifier every are inserted into the derivation at PF. In this way, Lobeck explains the ungrammaticality of ellipsis in (45), where SPEC(N) is not filled, and fails to properly govern pro:

(45)
a. *I really liked this book and I know you’ll like [NP the [e]] too.
b. *I'd love to spend a few weeks in Hawaii and I know you'd like to spend at least [NP a [e]] there too.
c. *The committee endorses every bill the president proposes and the advisors approve just about [NP every [e]] too.
Lobeck remarks briefly on the failure of ellipsis in noun phrases in French, illustrated in (46–47):

(46)
*Jean a goûté du vin mais il n’a pas goûté [beaucoup[e]].
John tasted some wines, but he didn't taste many [e].

(47)
Jean a goûté du vin mais il n’en a pas goûté beaucoup [e].
John tasted some wines but he of-them didn't like many [e].

Lobeck follows Milner (1978b) in analyzing the empty category in (47) as the N′ trace of en, adopting also Kayne's (1981b) and Hendrick's (1983) arguments that the trace of en is licensed by lexical government. This accounts for the subject/object asymmetry illustrated by comparing (47) with (48) (see also Haik 1982):

(48)
*Beaucoup [e] en ont goûté.
Many [e] of-them have tasted.

In (48), the trace of en is not lexically governed by the verb, and the derivation violates the ECP. Lobeck takes this as evidence that empty categories in NP are not licensed by specifier government in French; rather, the language relies on a different (clitic en) strategy to license empty categories. (46) is ungrammatical where the en strategy is not employed.

In a comprehensive study of a range of phenomena in English NP, including ellipsis, Olsen (1987) proposes an analysis of ellipsis which crucially involves specifiers and an empty category, but which is not explicitly stated in terms of proper government and the ECP. Olsen's approach also distinguishes between ellipsis in noun phrases and substantive adjectival constructions, arguing for two types of empty N: empty anaphoric N (ellipsis) and empty N specified as [+human, +generic].

Olsen argues that ellipsis in noun phrases involves an empty anaphoric head N (distinct from pro), whose content is recoverable from a discourse antecedent. She proposes that only specifiers that can combine with empty N (and that do not interfere with its anaphoricity) can introduce empty N in ellipsis contexts. This situation holds in (49), but not (50), where, in the latter case, anaphoric N has attempted to combine with an attributive adjective, specified for incompatible features. N must be realized here as one, or be ruled out:
(49) John's car and Bill's [e]
(50) John's new car and Bill's old one/*[e]
Certain adjectives with appropriate features can combine with empty N that is not anaphoric, but specified as [+human, +generic], in ‘substantive’ adjectival constructions:
(51) the able [e]

For Olsen, then, there are two types of empty N, neither of which can be analyzed as pro, a designation reserved for empty pronominal noun phrases rather than empty heads. Though Olsen does not explicitly state the constraints on ellipsis in terms of ‘specifier government’, her analysis parallels Lobeck's in relying on feature specification of specifiers to explain the distribution of ellipted nominal projections in English.

The early work on ellipsis and the ECP re-emerges in later work in a Principles and Parameters framework in which proper government is analyzed in more detail as involving licensing and identification. At the same time, researchers are exploring the role of functional categories in X-Bar Theory, including the status of DET as a functional head of DP. Within this framework, ellipsis in noun phrases is reanalyzed as involving licensing and identification by a functional X-0 rather than a specifier.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Ellipsis in DP
subsection.p: One immediate problem with the notion of ‘specifier government’ is that it assumes that specifiers, rather than heads, can properly govern their sisters, namely intermediate projections of N (as noted by Contreras 1989). Possessive NPs in SPEC(N) are a good case in point, and fall outside of the typical definition of ‘proper governor’. The ‘DP Hypothesis’ (proposed originally by Brame 1982 and elaborated by Abney 1987 and others) provides an alternative framework within which to analyze licensing and identification in ellipsis constructions, as prenominal elements are analyzed as heads, rather than specifiers. The empty category in ellipsis constructions can therefore be analyzed as properly governed in most cases by the functional head DET, rather than by a (possibly phrasal) SPEC(N).

Torrego (1987) is the first to provide an ECP account of what can now be referred to as ellipsis in DP, arguing that certain determiners in Spanish, Catalan, and Portuguese license empty pronominal N heads in noun phrases. Torrego analyzes this empty category as pro, and extends Borer's (1986) argument that pro must be licensed by person features (AGR). Torrego's argument hinges on the contrastive distribution of elliptical noun phrases headed by the definite determiner el and the demonstrative este, and the types of modifiers required in NP when N is empty. In order to claim that el governs and thus properly governs (licenses) pro, Torrego adopts the DP hypothesis, assuming that determiners head DP, with pro in this case as the empty head of the NP complement of DET (as proposed by Hellan 1985 for headless nominals in Norwegian).

Torrego observes that el can apparently license empty N when N is modified by de + XP, as illustrated in (52a). (Torrego presents a few arguments that el is not a clitic, and hence that such constructions involve ellipsis. Suñer 1986 gives an opposing view.) Empty N modified by a ‘semantically contentful’ PP is ungrammatical, as illustrated in (52b):

(52)
a. El [e] de las Meninas no está en este museo.
‘The (one) of the Meninas is not in this museum.’
b. Presenciaron los *(asaltos) a las zonas urbanas.
‘They witnessed the (assaults) in the urban areas.’

Adjectival modifiers seem to have the same properties as de + XP modifiers with respect to ellipsis; empty N in such constructions is apparently licensed, as in (53). (54) illustrates further that such adjectival modifiers can ‘save’ ellipsis constructions that include semantically contentful PP modifiers:
(53) Los [e] verdes son bonitos.
‘The green (ones) are nice.’

(54)
a. *Leí los [e] sobre política.
‘I read the (ones) about politics.’
b. Leí los [e] cortos sobre política.
‘I read the short (ones) about politics.’

From these and other data Torrego concludes that the definite determiner in Spanish is too ‘weak’ to license empty N alone; the relevant person features for licensing are contributed by de + XP. ‘Stronger’ determiners, such as este/ese/aquel, are specified for person. Consequently, they license pro without the additional required de PP, as illustrated in (55):

(55)
a. También acaban de salir estos [e] sobre anatomía.
b. *También acaban de salir los [e] sobre anatomía.
‘There also just appear these/the (ones) about anatomy.’

Torrego concludes that de + XP modifiers, like adjectives, are [+N], and contribute the relevant AGR features to license empty N that are not contributed by the weak definite determiner. Demonstratives are specified for sufficient features to license pro, and thus empty N can occur without the additional presence of de + XP. (See also Schroten 1992, Brucart 1987, and Brucart and Gràcia 1986 for related discussion.)

As mentioned above, Contreras (1989) observes that an approach to ellipsis in terms of specifier government is ad hoc, as it extends the ECP to apply to both empty intermediate and maximal projections, and includes specifiers as well as heads in the class of proper governors. Aside from these theoretical considerations he shows that specifier government fails to account for certain empirical distinctions between English and Spanish, and thus must be rejected.

He critiques two parallel analyses of specifier government involving ellipsis in NP, Lobeck (1987) for English and Bosque (1986) for Spanish. Bosque argues that the relevant difference between Spanish and English is that in the former, the article agrees with the head noun in gender and number. Specifiers with this ‘rich agreement’ properly govern empty N or N′. This rich SPEC–HEAD agreement relation fails to hold between English articles and N, and specifier government fails. (Examples are from Contreras 1989.)

(56)
Vi al estudiante de física y al [e] de química.
‘I saw the student of physics and the (one) of chemistry.’

(57)
Dame este libro de física y ese [e] de química.
‘Give me this book on physics and that [book] on chemistry.’

Bosque attributes the ungrammaticality of (58) to the feature specification of Spanish possessives; unlike definite articles and demonstratives, possessives are not specified for gender and number, and hence fail as proper governors:

(58)
*Su libro sobre Borges es mejor que su [e] sobre Cortázar
‘His/her book on Borges is better than his/her [e] on Cortázar.’
As Contreras points out, Bosque's analysis fails to account for the failure of ellipsis in French, where in possessives, the head N agrees in gender and number with the specifier:

(59)
*mon livre de logique et ton [e] de littérature
‘my book on logic and yours [e] on literature’

Bosque also fails to explain the fact that in both English and Spanish, numerals (which are not also specified for gender) apparently specifier-govern empty nominal categories, as illustrated in (60):

(60)
María compró tres libros de fisica y Juan compró dos [e].
‘Mary bought three books on physics and John bought two [e].’

And finally, an approach restricted to gender as a “rich” agreement feature fails to explain why certain, but not all, quantifiers appear to properly govern empty nominals in both English and Spanish:

(61)
a. Si bien algunos estudiantes quieren reformas, muchos [e] no la quieren.
b. Although some students want reforms, many [e] don't want them.
c. A propósito de estudiantes, varios [e] quieren verte.
d. Speaking about students, several [e] want to see you.

(62)
a. *Aunque no todo politico miente todo [e] es vanidoso.
b. *Although not every politician lies-every [e] is vain.
c. *Si cada [e] tiene una solucion diferente, nunca resolvere todos estos problemas.
‘If each has a different solution, I’ll never solve all these problems.’

To resolve the various problems with specifier government, Contreras adopts Fukui and Speas's (1986) theory of phrase structure (adapted from Brame's 1981, 1982 original proposal), in which functional categories (DET, COMP, and INFL) head phrases and project to X″. Lexical categories N, V, A, and P project to X′ as maximal. This distinction in what is analyzed as maximal is predicated on the assumption that only functional categories ‘discharge’ Kase features to a specifier position, and hence project beyond X′. Kase features include tense and agreement in INFL, [+poss] in DET, and [+WH] in COMP. Contreras proposes that only functional categories can properly govern ellipted nominal projections; hence, only DET specified for certain features that are appropriately “rich” can do so. The article in Spanish is so specified, but the English article is not. He suggests further that the evidence that DET specified as [+poss] can properly govern an ellipted complement suggests that the feature [+poss] qualifies as an appropriately “rich” agreement feature, and DET properly governs N′ (a maximal projection, according to Fukui and Speas):
(63) John's book was good, but [DP Mary [D 's [N′ e]] was even better.

Most of Contreras's arguments concern the status of quantifiers as functional heads. He analyzes certain quantifiers as members of the category Q, heading QP. He supports this hypothesis with evidence that just those quantifiers that properly govern empty nominals select either DP or partitive PP complements. Todo/all thus contrasts with cada/every in this way, as illustrated in (64–65). (See Giusti 1991a and Löbel 1989 for arguments that Q is a functional head, and Karimi 1989 and Rothstein 1988 for discussion of the phrase structure of quantified NPs in English. See also Van Riemsdijk 1989a for discussion of the distribution of a somewhat different type of empty category in German DP, introduced by a determiner specified for certain features.)

(64)
a. todo los problemas/todo del trabajo
b. all the problems/all of the work

(65)
a. *cada los problemas/*cada de los estudiantes
b. *every the problems/*every of the students

Contreras suggests that cada and every are specifiers, and sisters to N′. Todo and all, on the other hand, are quantifiers that can head QP, and select maximal projections as complements. In such configurations, the functional category Q, an X-0 rather than a specifier, properly governs [e]. In this way he predicts not only the distribution of ellipted nominal categories in (64–65), but also the contrast between (62a) above, and (66):

(66)
Estoy dispuesto a haver una parte del trabajo, pero no todo [e].
‘I'm willing to do part of the work, but not all.’
In (66), todo selects a DP complement, which can be empty. In contrast, in (62a) todo is a sister to N′ and thus a specifier rather than a head. Proper government fails, and ellipsis is ruled out.

Contreras claims that quantifiers can occupy SPEC(N), in which case they do not properly govern [e], or they fill Q, and are proper governors of DP. Yet a third option is for quantifiers to head QP and to select an N′ complement, a maximal projection in Fukui and Speas's framework. Thus he accounts for the grammaticality of ellipsis in (61a) above, though muchos/many does not select DP. These facts are illustrated in (67):

(67)
a. muchos de los estudiantes
b. *muchos los estudiantes
c. many of the students
d. *many the students

Contreras argues, contra previous accounts in which ellipted categories are analyzed as pro, that [e] in DP is [−anaphor, −pronominal], though it is not bound by an operator (as are other such categories, namely wh-trace). The empty category is thus a contextually defined variable, consistent with proposals such as that of Koopman and Sportiche (1982). In the framework he adopts, the ellipted category in noun phrases in Spanish is also analyzed as either N or N′, a claim also made by Torrego (1987), and by Ronat (1977) for French. (For discussion of N′ ellipsis in Japanese, and how it supports the DP hypothesis, see Saito and Murasugi 1990.)

subsection.heading: 4.3 Licensing and identification in DP
subsection.p: In a number of articles throughout the 1990s Lobeck refines the licensing and identification conditions on ellipted categories in DP, focusing on how to best formulate the feature specifications of DET and Q that appear to designate these heads with agreement ‘strong’ enough to license and identify NP pro complements of these heads (Lobeck 1990, 1991a, 1991b, 1993). One central issue is that while both the singular numeral one and the singular quantifier each license empty NP, singular every does not.

Lobeck originally argues that numerals and quantifiers, including singular one and each, are [+number], and specified for strong agreement. She adopts Contreras's proposal that every, on the other hand, though [+number] in her framework, fills SPEC(N) rather than Q, and is thus not a possible licensing head for an empty nominal projection. Lobeck (1995) later revises this approach, ultimately arguing that the relevant feature specification of quantifiers and numerals is not [+number], but [+partitive]. In this way Lobeck includes both singular one and each, both of which can occur in partitive constructions in English, in the set of potential licensing heads for ellipsis without the stipulation that these singular heads are [+number], and without requiring every to occur in a structural position different from each. In her framework, DET must be specified as [+poss], [+number] (more specifically, [+plural]), and/or [+partitive] to license and identify pro in DP. Every is therefore excluded as a licenser of ellipsis because it is both [−number] and [−partitive].

Lobeck also argues, following Ritter (1991), that numerals head NUMP, proposing that NUM specified for strong agreement can also license and identify pro in NUMP. In addition, Lobeck attempts a cross-linguistic analysis of ellipsis in DP based on evidence from German and French, proposing a parameter whereby the number of strong agreement features in DET or NUM that is required to identify an empty pronominal NP is proportional to the number of possible strong agreement features in the language. English, a language with relatively poor agreement, requires fewer strong agreement features to license ellipsis (at least one). French, with a somewhat more complex agreement system, requires more features than English (namely at least two), and German, with an even richer system, requires that DET, NUM, or Q be specified for three features. (For a critique of Lobeck's analysis of ellipsis in German DP, see Sleeman 1996, discussed below, and Winkler 1997, who argues that ellipsis is in part predictable based on pitch accent and focus.)

Kester's (1992, 1993, 1994, and other work, notably 1996a, 1996b) central insight is that, in a range of Germanic and Romance languages, a functional head in a SPEC–HEAD agreement relation with an adjective with morphological inflection is specified for “strong” agreement, and licenses empty N. (See also Delsing 1992 for discussion of the role of adjectival inflection in Scandinavian languages, and Olsen 1989 for German.) The empty non-anaphoric N in substantive adjective constructions and empty anaphoric N in ellipsis constructions are licensed in this way. They differ, however, in how empty N is identified. Non-anaphoric N is identified through special adjectival morphology, or by the grammatical gender features of the determiner. Anaphoric N, on the other hand, is identified with a lexical antecedent in the discourse. In Kester's approach, empty N is licensed by an adjective lacking strong agreement only in the default case, namely when N is specified as [+human, +generic, +plural]. (Kester adopts Lobeck's claim that empty N is pro, noting that in Dutch, for example, pro = N, while in English, pro = N′.)
To see how this analysis works, consider (68) (from Lobeck 1993, analyzed in Kester 1996b):

(68)
Ich möchte das alte Buch kaufen aber Sie möchten das neue [e].
I wanted the old book to buy but you wanted the New [e].
‘I wanted to buy the old book but you wanted to buy the new one.’

Lobeck argues that in (68), the adjective neue is a head specified for strong agreement features, based on evidence that adjectives in German express gender, case, number, etc. Adjectives in English lack these features, and thus are not specified for strong agreement and fail to license and identify pro in DP. Kester adopts Cinque's (1993) proposal that adjectives are specifiers of functional projections in DP, arguing that it is instead the functional head (F), in a SPEC–HEAD agreement relation with A specified for strong agreement, that licenses pro in (68). This situation is illustrated in (69):
(69) [DP [D′ das [FP neue [F′ [NP e]]]
Empty N in (69) is identified with its discourse antecedent, and is grammatical.

In (70), empty N is allowed in English, though A lacks features. Kester argues that this is because in English, empty N that is not identified by strong agreement can only survive if it is specified for and identified through its default features [+human, +generic, +plural]. Licensing conditions are also in this default case relaxed, and pro is licensed under government by the functional head F:

(70)
a. the sick
b. [DP [D′ the [FP sick [F′ [NP e]]]]]

In Dutch, on the other hand, non-anaphoric pro is [+human, +generic] but can be [+/−plural]. Empty N in this case is therefore not specified for default features, and thus falls under more stringent licensing and identification conditions. Ellipsis in Dutch DP also differs from English, in that empty anaphoric N can be licensed by an adjective. These facts are illustrated in (71–72) and (73), respectively:

(71)
[Rijken pro] worden alleen maar rijker.
rich pro
become all more rich
‘The rich only become richer.’

(72)
[Een zieke pro] heeft recht op een goede verzorging.
a sick pro
has a right to a good care
‘A sick person has a right to good care.’

(73)
Jan kocht de rode auto en [de groene pro].
Jan bought the red car and the green pro
‘John bought the red car and the green (one).’

Kester accounts for this difference between English and Dutch in terms of the presence or absence of adjectival inflectional morphology. In Dutch, adjectives in both substantive adjective and ellipsis constructions are inflected with -e (schwa). She argues that in these cases pro is licensed by this adjectival inflection, and in ellipsis constructions such as (73), pro is interpreted under identity with an antecedent (identification). In the substantive adjective constructions in (71–72), non-anaphoric pro is identified by grammatical gender features on the determiner.

Kester extends her analysis to a number of other languages (including German, Swedish, Spanish, and Finnish), concluding that adjectival inflection plays a crucial role in licensing both elliptical and non-elliptical empty N, and that the crucial difference between such constructions lies in the means by which identification conditions are met.

Bernstein's work (1991, 1993a, 1993b) concerns the distribution of the indefinite article in construction with empty N in Spanish and Italian (and also extends to French and Catalan). She argues that terminal vowels on nouns are functional heads, generated independently of their N stems. These functional heads can in turn license null projections of N. Because they are affixes, they must also raise to D, deriving the various orders of determiners, adjectives, and empty N in elliptical constructions in these languages. Her analysis thus provides yet another approach to ‘strong’ agreement in licensing empty N.

One central distributional difference that Bernstein observes is that in Spanish and Italian, the indefinite article occurs in ellipsis constructions only when affixed with -o. Other numerals and quantifiers are not so constrained:

(74)
Uno rojo está encima de la mesa
‘a red one is on the table’

(75)
*Quiero un (grande)
‘I want a (big)’

(76)
Quiero dos.
‘I want two.’

(77)
Tengo muchos.
‘I have many.’

(78)
Ne voglio due.
‘CL (I) want two.’

(79)
Ne ho molti.
‘CL (I) have many.’

She captures this distinction by arguing that in Spanish and Italian, DP dominates another functional category, Word Marker Phrase (WMP), headed by -o. The affix -o undergoes head-to-head movement, raising from WM to NUM to D. In D, -o adjoins to un-, the head of a QP in SPEC(NUMP) that has raised to D. In general, then, uno derives from head-to-head movement of two separate heads, the Q un and the WM -o. WM is a functional head that governs and licenses empty N in ellipsis constructions, accounting for the contrast between (74) and (75) above.

To explain the distribution of substantive adjectival constructions in (80), Bernstein proposes two different positions for adjectives (following Cinque 1993). Pobre occurs below WM, and mero above it. In the former case, raising of WM to D is not blocked, but in the latter case movement is blocked by mero, and the derivation is ruled out:

(80)
a. uno pobre (an impoverished one)
b. *uno mero (a mere one)

Bernstein generalizes her analysis to French, arguing that in this language WM is abstract, but present to govern and license an empty nominal projection. Consider, for example, (81–82), examples of empty nouns in French:

(81)
Un très gros chien vit dans cette maison. Un petit vit dans celle d’à côté.
‘A very big dog lives in this house. A small [e] lives in that one next door.’

(82)
un rouge
‘a red [e]’

She bases the grammaticality of (81–82) on the evidence that gender is reflected on some French nouns by an affix, -e, as illustrated in (83), suggesting that the final vowels in masculine nouns in French are deleted by a PF rule, but that they are present abstractly. French nouns thus are dominated by a WM projection just as in Spanish, and as a result, the invariable form un in French licenses empty N:

(83)
a. voisin/voisine
b. cousin/cousine
Bernstein also derives the difference between un/uno in partitive ne constructions from licensing by WM:

(84)
Ne ho visto uno/*un rosso
CL I have seen a red (one)
‘I have seen a red (one).’

Bernstein assumes, following Cinque (1991) and Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992), that ne is basically a clitic NP that raises to cliticize to the finite verb. This raising, she argues, is possible only when WM is present (as reflected by -o) to license the trace of ne.
In Bernstein's analysis then, ellipsis in Spanish, French, and Italian DP depends on licensing by a lexical or abstract functional category WM, the locus of gender affixes in Romance.

In a comprehensive study of ellipsis in French DP, Sleeman (1996) proposes a unified approach to licensing of empty N, or pro (in ellipsis, partitive, and substantive adjective constructions), defining ‘strong agreement’ for licensing in terms of a single, semantic feature, [+partitive]. Central to her analysis is the distribution of adjectives that can introduce empty N in French and other languages. Basically, she argues that adjectives are functional projections in DP, following Cinque (1993), but proposes that the relevant feature specification of the licensing head of such projections is [+partitive], rather than overt inflectional morphology. Only adjectives with this feature will be able to introduce ellipsis, as it is only in these contexts that the functional head with which the adjective agrees will be [+partitive], and able to license empty N. (For other approaches to French DP upon which Sleeman draws, see Corblin 1990; Valois 1991a, 1991b; Corver and Delfitto 1993.) Sleeman argues that this approach accounts for a number of contrasts first pointed out by Ronat (1977) and Barbaud (1976) for French, and also for certain cross-linguistic differences between French and Dutch, Spanish, Italian, and English.

Sleeman notes that while overt morphological inflection may be relevant to licensing empty N in Dutch and Spanish (as argued by Kester and Bernstein, respectively), morphological inflection does not seem relevant to licensing empty N in French. For example, the adjectives intéressante and grande, in (85) and (87) respectively, are both morphologically inflected for gender, but only grande licenses ellipsis. The adjectives vert foncé in (86) and facile in (88), on the other hand, both lack morphological inflection, but only the former licenses ellipsis:

(85)
*Malheureusement je n’ai pas entendu l’ intéressante.
unfortunately I neg have neg heard the interesting
‘Unfortunately, I have not heard the interesting one.’

(86)
De ces robes, je préfère la vert foncé.
of these dresses, I prefer the green deep
‘Of these dresses, I prefer the deep green one.’

(87)
Je prendrai la grande.
I will-take the big
‘I will take the big one.’

(88)
*Le facile se trouve à la page quarante.
the easy itself finds at the page forty.
‘The easy one is on page forty.’

To account for these and other contrasts, Sleeman proposes that only the functional head in a SPEC–HEAD agreement relation with a [+partitive] adjective licenses empty N. She distinguishes two classes of partitive words: D-partitives include cardinals, superlatives, ordinals, and words such as seul, autre, prochain, suivant. N-partitives include color adjectives and certain others including grand, petit, etc., all of which license empty N. Other adjectives do not license ellipsis (adjectives of quality, such as intéressante and facile).

Sleeman also derives the distribution of quantitative -en in French from licensing by a [+partitive] functional head. She argues that -en is inherently [+partitive], but that its empty counterpart, pro, is not, and must therefore be licensed by a [+partitive] head to be grammatical. It is not enough, however, that pro be licensed; it must also be identified by a [+specific] local element in order to be connected with an antecedent. (See Enç 1991 and Diesing 1992b for relevant discussion of specificity. For discussion of en/ne see Milner 1978b; Belletti and Rizzi 1981; Hulk 1982; Kayne 1984a; Cardinaletti and Giusti 1992.)
To illustrate, consider the data below:

(89)
Trois pro
arriveront demain.
three
will arrive tomorrow.
‘Three will arrive tomorrow.’

(90)
*J’ai lu trois. pro
I have read three pro
‘I have read three.’

(91)
J’en ai lu trois. pro
I of it/them have read three
‘I have read three.’

Sleeman explains the contrast between (89) and (90) by proposing that although pro is licensed by NUM (trois) specified as [+partitive], pro in (90) is in an indefinite object, and non-specific. The derivation is ruled out because pro is not identified. Sleeman assumes that subject DPs are specific, and thus that pro in (89) is licensed by a head specified as [+partitive], and is also specific, and thus identified. (91) is the counterpart of (90) where [+partitive, +specific] en is inserted, thus saving the derivation.

In (92), pro is identified by the [+partitive] PP, which also makes pro [+specific] (as noted by Cardinaletti and Giusti 1992). In (93), pro is specific because it is in a definite rather than indefinite DP (cf. (90)):

(92)
J’ai lu trois pro
de ses livres.
I have read three
of his books
‘I have read three of his books.’

(93)
Je préfère le troisième pro.
I prefer the third
‘I prefer the third.’

Sleeman extends her analysis to predict that only [+partitive] adjectives will introduce empty N in en constructions. This prediction seems to be borne out, as illustrated by the contrast between (94) and (95):

(94)
J’en ai acheté un rouge.
I of it have bought a red
‘I have bought a red one.’

(95)
*J’en ai rencontré un fâché.
I of it have met an angry
‘I have met an angry one.’
In Sleeman's account, only rouge, not fâché, is [+partitive] and licenses empty N.

Sleeman's analysis makes a number of interesting cross-linguistic predictions, one of which is that partitive adjectives, in contrast to other types of adjectives, should in fact license ellipsis in DP, contrary to Lobeck's claim that adjectives lack strong agreement and fail to license pro in English. Sleeman presents the data in (96) in support of this claim (examples are from Halliday and Hasan 1976):

(96)
a. Of the boys, I prefer the eldest pro.
b. I like your dress. I will buy the same pro as you.
c. Take this piece. I will take the other pro.
d. The green pro suits you very well.

The grammaticality of ellipsis in (96) suggests for Sleeman that D-partitive adjectives license pro in English. That (97) is ungrammatical is explained by claiming that in contrast to French, N-partitive adjectives do not license ellipsis in English, the color adjective in (96) being an exception:
(97) I will take the small *(one).

Sleeman extends her approach to substantive adjectives, arguing that in French, such constructions do not involve a syntactic empty N, though empty N is present at a lexical level. She again diverges from other analyses that argue that substantive adjective constructions involve pro licensed by morphological inflection.

subsection.heading: 5 Conclusion: current research directions
subsection.p: As we can see from the studies discussed here, research on what can now be analyzed as ellipsis in DP has made important contributions to our understanding of the nature of empty categories, the internal structure of the noun phrase, the properties of morphological inflection and semantic features of functional categories in licensing and identification, and the relationships between ellipsis and other phenomena, including partitive constructions (with clitic ne/en) and substantive adjective constructions.

Some subsequent work on ellipsis in DP, based on the foundations outlined here, includes Coene (1999) on ellipsis in DP in Romanian and Spanish, Giannakidou and Stavrou (1999) on object ellipsis in Greek, Martí Girbau (1999) on partitives and ellipsis in Catalan, López (2000) on ellipsis in DP and D-linking, Luján (2000) and Kester and Sleeman (2002) on an alternative analysis to ellipsis in Spanish, Pollock (1998) and Kupferman (1999) on noun ellipsis and the clitic en, and Panagiotidis (2002, 2003a, 2003b) on the status of the empty noun and one.
